entry.title: Daniel Davis (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Daniel Davis was the first person in the United States to work with gold and silver electroplating (illustrated) as a business?

entry.title: dance school in Dresden, Germany (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Gret Palucca had to close her dance school in Dresden, Germany, in 1939 because of her Jewish descent, but reopened it in 1945?

entry.title: Ashton Hawkins (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Ashton Hawkins arranged for the construction of the West Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City, to house the Temple of Dendur?

entry.title: Malyuk (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Malyuk rifle was originally developed as a private venture under a contract with the Security Service of Ukraine?

entry.title: Ali Audah (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Indonesian translator Ali Audah would often take hours to translate a single word or sentence?

entry.title: Das eine Brot wächst auf vielen Halmen (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the 1972 hymn "Das eine Brot wächst auf vielen Halmen", with an Israeli melody, has been used for Catholic Corpus Christi processions and Protestant Kirchentag conventions?

entry.title: magnetoreception (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that magnetoreception in birds works by quantum effects in their eyes?

entry.title: The Cage (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that at the premiere of The Cage, a ballet about female insects preying on their male counterparts, choreographer Jerome Robbins's mother walked out of the theater?
